udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

goals.goal_text: By (date), when given a grade-level story, (name) will track the words on each page using his/her finger from left to right and top to bottom for a total of (4) pages in (4 of 5) books read.
goals.instruction_text: Teachers can have students chorally chant the nursery rhyme while pointing to the words being read on a poster size paper. Students can have turns pointing to the words left to right, top to bottom as the class chants the nursery rhyme.
goals.measurement_text: Teachers can ask students to point to the correct words (showing awareness of left to right top to bottom) as the  class and or teacher reads/chants the words to a nursery rhyme.
goals.modification_text:
UDL I 1.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer ways of customizing the display of information
When chanting the story or nursery rhyme teachers can first model the choral chant by speaking clearly with a steady rate and volume.

UDL I 1.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer ways of customizing the display of information
Teachers can complete the activity using enlarged text, poster or a document camera so that the text that can be enlarged.

UDL II 5.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple media for communication
Teachers can provide opportunities for students to use a ruler or pointer to lead the class choral chant activity.

UDL II 5.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple media for communication
Teachers can explicitly teach gestures and physical movements for students to perform while completing the reading activity.

objectives.text: By (date), after watching a teacher [[modeling behaviors|model]] how to track the words in a [[big books|big book]], when given a grade-level story, (name) will track the words on each page using his/her finger from left to right and top to bottom for a total of (4) pages in (4 of 5) books read.

By (date), after watching a teacher [[modeling behaviors|model]] how to track the words in a [[ familiar text|familiar]] [[big books|big book]], when given an instructional-level big book, (name) will track the words on each page using a pointer from left to right and top to bottom for a total of (2) pages in (3 of 5) books read.

By (date), during a small-group reading activity, when all students [[choral reading|read aloud in unison]] a [[familiar text|familiar]], instructional-level [[big books|big book]], (name) will use a pointer to track the words on each page from left to right and top to bottom, for a total of (1) page in (3 of 5) books read.

goals.parent_text: Understand print is organized from left to right, top to bottom.
goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Track Print

udl_adaptations.text: Rather than just reading a text [[read aloud|aloud]] and expecting students to follow the words from left to right top to bottom from their voice, the teacher can provide an [[adapted text|audio CD of the book]] (e.g., bell chimes when it is time to turn each page) to listen to as the student tracks the text of each page.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 1.2 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer alternatives for auditory information
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 1.2 Offer alternatives for auditory information

udl_adaptations.text: In order to vary the methods of response for teaching a student how to track the words in a text, the teacher can allow students to track using their fingers, pointers, yard stickers, markers, etc. This can make the activity more engaging for the student by giving him/her a choice as to how they will respond to a prompt to track a text.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: Teachers can create a class routine where students [[ read aloud | chant the text ]] and demonstrate correct tracking of text together in a group setting. Teachers can also have students [[modeling behaviors|model]] the correct tracking of text in front of their peers during the group reading activity.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Minimize threats and distractions
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.3 Minimize threats and distractions

goals.goal_text: By (date) when given (10) pictures of common signs, labels, and their own name, (name) will read each word out loud scoring (8/10) correctly read words in (2 out of 3) common word activities.
goals.modification_text:
UDL I [X.X] Provide Multiple Means of Representation: [Checkpoint Name]

Instead of [means of representation assumed in grade level goal], [example(s) of the checkpoint specifically for this goal]

 

UDL II [X.X] Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: [Checkpoint Name]

Instead of [means of action and expression assumed in grade level goal], [example(s) of the checkpoint specifically for this goal]

 

UDL III [X.X] Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: [Checkpoint Name]

If student [why student might need more engagement], [example of UDL Principle III]

objectives.text: By (date), on a learning walk around the school, when shown (10) common signs, labels, and their own name, (name) will read each word out loud scoring (8/10) correctly read words in (2 out of 3) common word activities.

By (date) when given (10) pictures of common signs, labels, and their own name, (name) will chorally chant each word out loud with a small group of (6-9) students scoring (8/10) correctly chanted words in (2 out of 3) common word activities.

By (date), on a one on one learning walk around the school with the teacher, when shown (5) common signs, labels, and their own name, (name) will point to the word seen and chorally chant each word out loud with the teacher scoring (4/5) correctly chanted words in (2 out of 3) common word activities.

goals.parent_text: Recognize and read your name and words that appear on common signs and labels.
goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Recognize Common Words

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of teachers only reviewing the goal of how many common words the student is expected to know and the amount of current correct responses, together with the student, teachers can graph the number of correct responses after each activity along side the expected number of sight words or the student's goal. This can help students visualize the expected level of performance and teach them how to set obtainable academic goals while also motivating them to reach their goal. Teachers can also establish a given reward for reaching the expected number of words (e.g. when you can read 8 common words we can have a popcorn movie party).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Develop self-assessment and reflection
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.3 Develop self-assessment and reflection

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of teachers showing students pictures of common signs and labels, teachers can take students on a learning walk to look at the signs and labels that exist all over the school. While walking teachers can point out each sign and label, say the word out loud and have the students repeat the word.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 1.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer ways of customizing the display of information
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 1.1 Offer ways of customizing the display of information

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students having to independently read the word shown on the picture of a common sign or label, students can chant or chorally restate each word with a group students.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_text: By (date), during a [[ Read aloud| read aloud]] of a grade level [[illustration| illustrated]] story, after the teacher models making connections to his/her own life (e.g. "The dog in this story sleeps all day just like my dog Molly." or "My older brother used to tease me just like the character's older sister teases him."), (name) will make (2) spoken connections between him/herself and the story, for (2 out of 3) trials.
goals.modification_text:
UDL I [X.X] Provide Multiple Means of Representation: [Checkpoint Name]

Instead of [means of representation assumed in grade level goal], [example(s) of the checkpoint specifically for this goal]

 

UDL II [X.X] Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: [Checkpoint Name]

Instead of [means of action and expression assumed in grade level goal], [example(s) of the checkpoint specifically for this goal]

 

UDL III [X.X] Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: [Checkpoint Name]

If student [why student might need more engagement], [example of UDL Principle III]

objectives.text: By (date), during a [[ Read aloud| read aloud]] of a grade level [[illustration| illustrated]] story, after the teacher models making connections to his/her own life, (name) will use [[ Sentence starters| sentence starters]] (e.g. The story reminds me of a time when I _____. or The character _____ is just like _____.) to make (2) spoken connections between him/herself and the story, for (2 out of 3) trials.

By (date), during a [[ Read aloud| read aloud]] of an instructional level [[illustration| illustrated]] story, after the teacher models making connections to his/her own life, (name) will use the book to recall the events and make (1) spoken connection between him/herself and the story, given no more than (2) verbal prompts from the teacher (i.e. "How is this character like you?" or "Do you see anything on this page that you see at home or in this classroom?"), for (2 out of 3) trials.

By (date), after watching a short video of his/her choice and viewing [[illustration| illustrations]] that reference something seen in the video, (name) will verbally respond to (5) yes/no questions about whether the student has ever tried the activities in the illustrations, scoring (4 out of 5) correct responses, for (2 out of 3) trials.

goals.parent_text: Undertand how to make connections between self, illustrations and the story.
goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Making Connections Between Self and a Story

udl_adaptations.text: Teachers can provide [[sentence starters| sentence stems]] to help students structure their responses. The stems provide a framework for constructing connections to the story that teach students to clearly express themselves and to link information from two different sources.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.4 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Maximize transfer and generalization
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.4 Maximize transfer and generalization

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of teachers reading a story and asking students questions, teachers can "think-aloud" to model how to appropriately make connections between the information given in the story and their lives.  After teachers have modeled making connections to the story, they can have students attempt to make their own connections to the story.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 6.2 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Support planning and strategy development
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 6.2 Support planning and strategy development

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of reading a story that is about an unfamiliar topic, teachers can select a story with familiar characters or subject matter. The teacher can use the students' background knowledge to engage them in the story and help them connect to it. For example, if the text is about fish, the teacher can ask the students if they have ever seen fish at an aquarium or have gone fishing and guide a class discussion around fish before reading the story.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.2 Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

goals.goal_text: By (date), after independently reading a grade-level fictional text (e.g., short story, novel, poem) and experiencing a [[Guided Peer Discussions|guided peer discussion]] that generates a list of important events, (name) will identify a scene that is critical to the development of the story and write a brief paragraph (6-8 sentences) that describes the story’s theme and lists at least (2) ways the scene moves the plot forward in (4 out of 5) passages.

objectives.text: By (date), after a a [[Read Aloud|read aloud]] (e.g., book on tape, [[Reader's Theater|reader’s theater]]) of a grade-level fictional text, (name) will identify a scene that is critical to the development of the story through a [[Guided Peer Discussions|guided peer discussion]] and use a [[Graphic Organizers|story map]] to write a brief paragraph (6-8 sentences) that describes the story’s theme and lists at least (2) ways the scene moves the plot forward in (4 out of 5) passages.

By (date), after reading a fictional text at his/her [[Modified Text|instructional level]], and given a specific scene that is critical to the development of the story, (name) will complete a [[Graphic Organizers|story map]] that identifies the story’s theme and lists at least (2) ways the scene moves the plot forward in (4 out of 5) passages.

By (date), after experiencing a [[Picture Walk|picture walk]] of a fictional text (e.g., short story, novel poem) and given [[Picture Choices|picture choices]], (name) will identify (1) picture that represents the theme of a story and at least (1) other related picture (by pointing, using an assistive communication device, etc.) in (4 out of 5) trials.

goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Analyze a Scene's Impact on Plot

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of the student reading text in written form, alternatives such a [[Read Aloud|read alouds]] and [[Picture Walk|picture walks]] allow students to access content through audio, visual and kinesthetic means.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 1.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer alternatives for visual information
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 1.3 Offer alternatives for visual information

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students organizing and managing information about what they have read on their own, teachers can provide organizational supports like [[Graphic Organizers|graphic organizers]] and [[Open Notes|open notes]] to help students organize information and stay organized from start to finish as they complete the writing assignment.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 6.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Facilitate managing information and resources
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 6.3 Facilitate managing information and resources

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of receiving feedback at the end of an assignment, students can benefit from feedback throughout the instructional process. Students can [[Self-Monitoring|self-monitor]], work with a [[Peer Editing|peer]] to edit or receive support, and can look at [[exemplar|models]] of other students' work to complete a task.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.4 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Increase mastery-oriented feedback
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.4 Increase mastery-oriented feedback

goals.goal_text: By (date), when given a list of (10) irregularly spelled grade level words, (student) will independently orally read and pronounce each word with 100% accuracy in (4 out of 5) trials.

objectives.text: By (date), when given a list of (10) irregularly spelled grade level words, and, after the student has orally read and written each word (5-10) times immediately prior, (student) will independently orally read and pronounce each irregularly spelled word with 100% accuracy in (4 out of 5) trials.

By (date), when given a list of (10) irregularly spelled grade level words, and, after the student has orally read each word and formed each word using [[ Letter/Word Tiles | letter tiles ]] with a [[ Peer Tutoring | partner ]] immediately prior, (student) will orally read and pronounce each irregularly spelled word with 100% accuracy in (4 out of 5) trials.

By (date), when the teacher reads aloud (10) instructional level sentences, each containing an irregularly spelled instructional level word and orally states (2) [[ Multiple Choice | possible pronunciations ]] for each word, (student) will orally identify the correct pronunciation with 100% accuracy in (4 out of 5) trials.

goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Read Irregularly Spelled Words

udl_adaptations.text: Most academic areas require memorization of facts or information at some level. Memorization can often be challenging for some students. In order to develop automaticity, such as the memorization of irregularly spelled words in this lesson, it is essential to offer other alternatives for understanding and practice. In this lesson, [[Letter/Word Tiles| letter tiles]] may provide a kinesthetic alternative to pen and paper spelling of words.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.5 Illustrate through multiple media

udl_adaptations.text: For struggling readers, it can often be difficult to decode and pronounce unfamiliar words. In this lesson, after [[Modeling Behaviors| appropriate modeling]] by the teacher, the student can listen to a [[Multiple Choice |selection of possible pronunciations]] and identify the most correct pronunciation.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

udl_adaptations.text: [[Peer Tutoring|Peer Tutoring]] is a beneficial strategy in promoting collaboration and communication among learners. In this lesson, the teacher may choose to have the students read the irregularly spelled words with a partner. The students can work together to practice their fluency and automaticity of each word.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster collaboration and communication
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.3 Foster collaboration and communication

goals.goal_text: By (date), when given a set of (3-4) [[ picture story telling | story cards ]] based on a recently read, grade level story, and [[Verbal Prompting | verbal prompts]] to put them [[ picture sequencing | in order ]] (e.g. "Please put them in the proper order."), (name) will independently place the cards in the correct sequential order for (4 out of 5) sessions.

objectives.text: By (date), after completing a [[ Picture Walk | picture walk ]] of a recently read, grade level story, and when given a set of (3-4) [[ picture story telling | story cards ]], and [[Verbal Prompting | verbal prompts]] to put the story cards [[ picture sequencing | in order ]] (e.g. "Please put them in the proper order."), (name) will independently place the cards in the correct sequential order for (4 out of 5) sessions.

By (date), after completing a [[ Picture Walk | picture walk ]] of a recently read, instructional level story, and when given a set of (3-4) [[ picture story telling | story cards ]], placed with a [[ Partner Reading | reading partner ]] and [[Verbal Prompting | verbally prompted]] to put the story cards [[ picture sequencing | in order ]] (e.g. "Please put them in the proper order."), (name) will place the cards in the correct sequential order for (4 out of 5) sessions.

By (date), after completing a [[ Picture Walk | picture walk ]] of a recently read, instructional level story, and when given a set of (2) [[ picture story telling | story cards ]] and [[Verbal Prompting | verbal]] and [[ Visual cueing | visual prompts]] by the teacher to place the story cards in order (e.g. “Think about what happens first. Put the first card here.” Teacher points to the spot where the first card should go.), (name) will place the cards in the correct sequential order for (3 out of 5) sessions.

goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Using Sequential Order

udl_adaptations.text: Even with familiar stories, and the support of picture cards, demanding a properly sequenced retelling may be overwhelming for our youngest students. Supporting students with a [[ Picture Walk | picture walk ]] to remind them of the story may allow some students to independently succeed with this goal. A picture walk may be done independently or may be accompanied with a retelling of the story by the teacher, depending on the students' immediate needs. For this social studies goal, [[ http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/delivering-your-mail-ann-owen/1005760567?ean=9781404804852 | Delivering Your Mail, by Ann Owens ]] is a great choice for a book, reinforcing content from social studies and providing material that is easily adapted into story cards for sequencing (e.g. The steps of how mail is delivered).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

udl_adaptations.text: Some students, particularly those with memory or processing difficulties, may struggle to independently order a set of illustrated picture cards. If a picture walk and retelling do not facilitate success, the support of a [[ Partner Reading | reading partner ]] may be sufficient for the student to correctly order the picture cards. The support of a partner may be gradually reduced over time, as the student becomes familiar with and improves in sequencing. Watching a trusted peer physically manipulate the cards may be enough, in itself, to propel a student into completing the task independently.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

udl_adaptations.text: For some students, an independent or even partner-supported undertaking of sequencing may be overwhelming. A student with social difficulties may balk at the intimacy of a partner, while others may not benefit from the visual support of a picture walk. Allowing these students to work on sequencing cards as the class [[ Choral Reading | chorally reads ]] the story can relieve social pressure while providing auditory support. The choral reading might also be paired with visual cueing from the teacher.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

goals.goal_text:
After independently reading a grade-level short story (less than 20 pages) from outside the United States, (student) will write a (3) paragraph analysis of the author’s point-of-view in the story that identifies (3) factors impacting the author’s point-of-view (e.g. race, culture, class, beliefs, religion, experiences), explains how (2 or more) story elements are affected by these factors, presents the author’s overall theme in writing the text, and analyzes whether this theme is consistent with the author’s point-of-view.

Click for an [[https://docs.google.com/document/d/1G0gUVepTFrSrFygIhkn9s5NCHdcWn2GLgz5mDFMIJjk/edit | example essay]] based on this task.

objectives.text: After independently reading a short story from outside the United States, (student) will use a [[ Graphic Organizers | graphic organizer]] [[https://docs.google.com/document/d/1L0zhtDlvLObs9qGySlHHqE1z8DZg5_GP5c4qIRHSDsg/edit?usp=sharing | (sample included)]] to outline and write a (3) paragraph analysis of the author’s point-of-view in the story that identifies (3) factors impacting the author’s point-of-view (e.g. race, culture, class, beliefs, religion, experiences), explains how (2 or more) story elements are affected by these factors, presents the author’s overall theme in writing the text, and analyzes whether this theme is consistent with the author’s point-of-view.

After reading a short story at (his/her) instructional level from outside the United States with a group of peers, (student) will use a [[Graphic Organizers | graphic organizer]] to outline and write an analysis of a central character's point-of-view in the story that explains how (2) or more  character factors (e.g. race, culture, class, beliefs, religion, experiences) influenced at least (2) actions of the character in (2 of 3) written responses.

After watching a video or dramatization of a story from outside the United States, (student) will  answer (4 out of 5) verbal questions that that ask the student to explain why a central character took a specific action using specific evidence from the text for (2 of 3) stories.

goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Analyze Point-of-View in World Literature

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of independently reading a short story, the story can be read aloud, be written in student’s native language, or accessed a second time through a film depicting the short story or novel.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.4 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Promote understanding across languages
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.4 Promote understanding across languages

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of giving students the prompt and releasing them for the assignment entirely independently, some students may require added structure from a [[Graphic Organizers | graphic organizer]] [[https://docs.google.com/document/d/1L0zhtDlvLObs9qGySlHHqE1z8DZg5_GP5c4qIRHSDsg/edit?usp=sharing | (sample template provided)]] that can prompt the students to think about aspects of an author's or character's point of view.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 6.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Facilitate managing information and resources
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 6.3 Facilitate managing information and resources

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of providing the same samples of world literature to all students, students may benefit from samples of world literature from a geography that is in their area of interest or from their own cultural heritage/background.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.2 Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

goals.goal_text: By (date), after reading an autobiographical grade level text (e.g. Through My Eyes - Ruby Bridges), (name) will write (2-3) sentences that identifies at least (1) similarity and (1) difference between (name) and the author in the areas of background, generation, social class, race, or location in (4 out of 5) texts.

objectives.text: By (date), after completing an activity on points of view (e.g. a “quick-write “describing the first day of school from the teacher’s point of view vs. the students’ point of view), after reading an autobiographical grade level text (e.g. Through My Eyes - Ruby Bridges), (name) will write (2-3) sentences after using a [[ Venn Diagram | Venn Diagram ]] to identify at least (1) similarity and (1) difference between (name) and the author in the areas of background, generation, social class, race, or location in (4 out of 5) texts.

By (date), after hearing an autobiographical grade level text read aloud, (name) will correctly answer (4 out of 5) multiple choice questions about the author in the areas of background, generation, social class, race, or location (e.g. “Ruby Bridges grew up in a __________ family (big, small).”) for (4 of 5) texts.

By (date), after listening to an short autobiographical passage at instructional level, (name) will sort (5) pairs of sentence strips (read aloud) into two groups: "About Me", "About the Author" for (4 out of 5) texts. One strip is a fact about the student (e.g. "I was born in Fresno, CA") and one strip is a fact about the author (e.g. "I was born in Columbia, SC")

goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Distinguish Point of View from Author's

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students completing this activity with no prior knowledge, some students may benefit from becoming familiar with different points of view prior to reading the text. For example,  teachers could lead an activity where students read a historical account and examine the events from the participants’ points of view (e.g. The Boston Tea Party from the British soldier and the Patriots perspective).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students verbally responding to questions about point of view or writing an analysis, students can sort sentence strips that represent various details about the author or themselves.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students reading through the entire text at once, some students may benefit from the text being chunked into smaller logical sections. Questions can immediately follow the reading of a chunk. Breaks can be used between chunks to manage students’ frustrations. Reading can be a difficult activity for many students, and an ability to take breaks through an activity could help them develop internal control.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Vary demands and resources to optimize challenge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.2 Vary demands and resources to optimize challenge

goals.goal_text: By (date), after reading a grade level story, (name) will restate (5) key details from the text scoring (4/5 correct spoken responses or 80% accuracy) in (4 of 5 trials) as measured by (teacher-charted records).
goals.instruction_text: Teachers can have students listen to a grade level text being read aloud, or have a student read a grade level text aloud.  After reading the story, have the student refer back to the text to restate 5 details or facts from the story.
goals.measurement_text: Teachers can read a story aloud or have the student read the story aloud.  After finishing the story, flip through the pages from start to finish, and ask the student questions regarding (5) key details or facts from the text.
goals.modification_text:
UDL I 1.2 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer alternatives for auditory information
Teachers can use visual prompts (i.e. pictures from the text) to guide student responses.

UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
Teachers can remind students of essential elements from stories read in the past (e.g. "remember the main characters from the story we read yesterday?"). In addition, teachers can connect story details to larger classroom units. For example, a story about fish may be used during a unit on oceans.

UDL II 5.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple media for communication
For students who struggle with verbal and written communication, teachers may ask students to indicate correct answers from a list of multiple choices by either pointing, or gesturing (e.g. nodding yes or no). For example, teachers may generate and read a list of names and ask students to indicate which names were in the story. When possible, teachers may have students indicate (e.g. by pointing) where that character's name appears in the text/story.

objectives.text: By (date), after reading a grade level story with [[ picture choices | pictures or illustrations ]] on each page, (name) will restate (5) key details from the text with (80)% accuracy in (4 of 5 trials) as measured by (teacher-charted records).

By (date), after reading a story at (name)'s [[ modified text | instructional level ]] with a [[ picture choices | pictures or illustration ]] on each page, (name) will restate (5) key details from the text when asked / prompted by a teacher with (80)% accuracy in (4 of 5 trials) as measured by (teacher-charted records).

By (date), after [[ read aloud | listening to or reading along to a story ]] at (name)'s [[ modified text | instructional level ]] with a visual support (e.g. picture) on each page, (name) will restate (5) key details from the text when asked / prompted by a teacher with (80)% accuracy in (4 of 5 trials) as measured by (teacher-charted records).

goals.parent_text: In one year, you will be able to talk about key information from a story.
goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Restate Facts from Text

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students reading plain text, some students may benefit from reading text with visual supports in the form of [[ picture choices | pictures or illustration ]]. Visuals embedded in text aids comprehension, especially for beginning readers.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 1.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer alternatives for visual information
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 1.3 Offer alternatives for visual information

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students restating key details from the text unprompted, teachers can ask the student 5 questions about key details. This will guide student responses and possibly spark their memory about specific key details.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students simply restating all the key details for the teacher, students could be rewarded with a sticker or token for each detail remembered. This positive reinforcer can be a strong motivator and self-assessment tool.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Develop self-assessment and reflection
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.3 Develop self-assessment and reflection

goals.goal_text: By (date), after participating in a [[ read aloud | read aloud ]] of a grade level story, (name) will state (1) character, the setting, and (1) major event/detail from the story in (4 out of 5 trials) as measured by student work samples.
goals.instruction_text: Teachers can model a "think-aloud" while reading an instructional-level text, being sure to point out the most important details of the text.
goals.measurement_text: Teachers can pair students together and ask them to ask and answer questions pertaining to characters, setting, and major events in the text. Students should be able to illustrate the main character and setting.
goals.modification_text:
UDL I 1.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer alternatives for visual information
Some students (e.g. with visual impairments) may find it difficult to engage with illustrations. Use other sensory descriptors to translate the content of illustrations (e.g. settings that are inside or outside, warm or cold, loud or quiet, etc.).

UDL II 6.2 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Support planning and strategy development
While reading a story with students, practice stopping after an important statement and noting (e.g. through discussion, or by physically highlighting, etc.) why this statement is important. Verbally prompt students by asking questions like, "why is this sentence important? What did we just learn about (_)?"

UDL III 7.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize Individual Choice and Autonomy
Allow the student to select from multiple texts based on areas of the student's personal interest

objectives.text: By (date), after participating in a [[ read aloud | read aloud ]] of a grade level story, using a [[ story mountain | story web ]], (name) will state (1) character, the setting, and (1) major event/detail from the story  in (4 out of 5 trials) as measured by student work samples.

By (date), after a thorough [[ preteaching | book introduction ]] and participating in a [[ read aloud | read aloud ]] of a familiar story, (name) will identify (1) character, the setting, and (1) major event/detail from the story by [[ illustration | illustrating ]] a picture with their answers in (4 out of 5 trials) as measured by student work samples.

By (date), after a thorough [[ preteaching | book introduction ]] and participating in a [[ read aloud | read aloud ]] of a familiar story, (name) will identify an [[ picture choices | illustration ]] that contains (1) character, the setting, and (1) major event/detail from the story in (4 out of 5 trials) as measured by teacher observation.

goals.parent_text: In one year, you will be able to describe characters, setting, and major events in text.
goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Identify Key Story Elements

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students participating in a typical read aloud, some students may benefit from teachers [[ preteaching | introducing the book ]] thoroughly before beginning to read. Teachers can show the students who the characters are, what the setting is, and any key events that will happen in the book prior to reading it.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 1.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer ways of customizing the display of information
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 1.1 Offer ways of customizing the display of information

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of remembering the key details from the story, some students may benefit from expressing their answer within a [[ story mountain | story web ]]. This visual aid may help some students formulate their thoughts about the main character, setting, and key events.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.2 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple tools for construction and composition
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.2 Use multiple tools for construction and composition

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students verbally responding with their answers, some students may benefit from [[ illustration | illustrating ]] the setting, character, and main event. This option may play to the strengths of some students who are more artistic and motivated by alternate activities such as drawing.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize individual choice and autonomy
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.1 Optimize individual choice and autonomy

goals.goal_text: By (date), after reading a grade level story, (name) will write a (3-5 sentence) paragraph describing the characters and their responses to (2) major events in (4 of 5 trials) as measured by (student work samples).
goals.instruction_text: Teachers can use character mapping to show characterization. On a graphic organizer, teachers can have students analyze the character and their decisions in the text.
goals.measurement_text: Teachers can evaluate this goal by asking students to illustrate or compose a character analysis.
goals.modification_text:
UDL II 6.2 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Support planning and strategy development
While reading a story with students, practice stopping after an important statement and noting (e.g. through discussion, or by physically highlighting, etc.) why this statement is important. Verbally prompt students by asking questions like, "why is this sentence important? What did we just learn about (_)?"

UDL II 6.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Facilitate managing information and resources
Emotion charts may be particularly useful for some students. Using an emotion chart, ask students to match (verbally, in writing, or by pointing) a character's response or action in a story to the correct emotion.

UDL III 7.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize Individual Choice and Autonomy
Allow the student to select from multiple texts based on areas of the student's personal interest

objectives.text: By (date), after reading a grade level story, (name) will verbally describe the characters and their responses to (2) major events in (4 of 5 trials) as measured by (student work samples).

By (date), after reading a story at (name)'s [[modified text | independent level]] with [[highlighting | highlighted]] key character responses to major events, (name) will verbally describe the characters and their responses to (2) major events in (4 of 5 trials) as measured by (student work samples).

By (date), after watching an instructional level [[video | film]] depicting a story, (name) will verbally or with an AC device, name the characters and a major event in the story in (4 of 5 trials) as measured by (teacher observation).

goals.parent_text: In one year, you will be able to describe how characters change within the story.
goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Describe Character Responses

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students reading the plain text, some students may benefit from teachers highlighting the major events in the story. This will help students organize their writing when talking about how a character reacts to the major events.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.2 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Clarify syntax and structure
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.2 Clarify syntax and structure

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students writing a paragraph about how characters react to events, some students may benefit from verbally describing it to a peer or teacher. This will allow struggling writers to express themselves more fully.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students completing this activity by themselves, some students may benefit from adjusting the social demand in the classroom. Some students may choose to do this activity within a group for support, while others may want a private, quiet environment.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Minimize threats and distractions
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.3 Minimize threats and distractions

goals.goal_text: By (date), when read a grade level story aloud, (name) will ask/answer (5) questions regarding unknown words in a text (e.g. "Can you find a word from the book that has the /p/ sound?") in (4 of 5 trials) as measured by (teacher-charted observation).
goals.instruction_text: Teachers can model a "think-aloud" strategy in which they ask and answer questions about the text they are reading aloud.
goals.measurement_text: After reading text aloud, teachers can observe pairs of students asking and answering questions about the words within the text.
goals.modification_text:
UDL I 1.2 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer alternatives for auditory information
Some students (e.g. with hearing impairments) may have trouble processing spoken words. When possible, provide written examples of unknown words in a text.

UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Minimize threats and distractions
Publicly identifying information that a student does not know can be intimidating. Maximize students' ability to participate by providing safe times and spaces for students to ask questions.

objectives.text: By (date), when read a grade level story aloud and specific words are [[ preteaching | previewed ]], (name) will ask/answer (5) questions regarding unknown words in a text (e.g. "Can you find a word that has the /p/ sound?") in (4 of 5 trials) as measured by (teacher-charted observation).

By (date), when a teacher [[ preteaching | previews ]] an assignment, reads a story at (name)'s independent reading level aloud and specific words are previewed, (name) will ask/answer (5) questions regarding unknown words in a text (e.g. "Can you find a word that has the /p/ sound?") in (4 of 5 trials) as measured by (teacher-charted observation).

By (date), when read a familiar story at (name)'s independent reading level aloud and specific words are [[ preteaching | previewed ]], (name) will answer (3) questions regarding unknown words in a text (e.g. "Can you find a word that has the /p/ sound?") by pointing to the desired words in the text in (4 of 5 trials) as measured by (teacher-charted observation).

goals.parent_text: In one year, you will be able to ask and answer questions about unknown words.
goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Ask About New Words

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students searching for unknown words throughout the book, some students may benefit from certain words being highlighted or previewed. Narrowing the perceived amount of work can give students the focus and confidence to succeed.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Clarify vocabulary and symbols
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.1 Clarify vocabulary and symbols

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students saying the desired word when asked a question, some students may benefit from pointing to the word within the book or screen. Many students who struggle with speech have the word identification skills and motor control to complete this task with the appropriate accommodations.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students asking and answering these questions after the book is read, some students may benefit from being made aware that they will be asking and answering questions about unknown words before reading. Making the goal salient for students can help sustain their concentration.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Heighten salience of goals and objectives
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.1 Heighten salience of goals and objectives

goals.goal_text: By (date), given (5) independent level literary (sentences) containing literal and nonliteral language, (name) will identify the meanings of (5) words in (4 out of 5 consecutive trials as measured by teacher-made tests and student work samples).
goals.instruction_text: Teachers can explicitly teach the difference between literal and nonliteral language. Teachers can have students illustrate the meaning of common forms of nonliteral language such as: it is raining cats and dogs.
goals.measurement_text: Given an instructionally appropriate text that includes literal and nonliteral language, students can identify the meaning of phrases when answering reading comprehension questions.
goals.modification_text:
UDL I 3.4 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Maximize transfer and generalization
When practicing particular idioms or other nonliteral figures of speech, encourage students not only to identify the phrase in a text, but also to use the phrase in a separate writing or speaking task.

UDL III 7.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize Individual Choice and Autonomy
Allow the student to select from multiple texts based on areas of the student's personal interest

objectives.text: By (date), when given brief sentences/passages containing literal and nonliteral language written at grade level, (name) will identify the meanings of (5) words from the definitions in a teacher-created word bank in (4 out of 5 consecutive trials as measured by teacher-made tests and student work samples).

By (date), when given brief sentences/passages containing literal and nonliteral language written at (name)'s independent level from a high interest text, (name) will identify the meanings of (5) words from the definitions in a teacher-created word bank in (4 out of 5 consecutive trials as measured by teacher-made tests and student work samples).

By (date), when read sentences containing literal and nonliteral language from a familiar high interest text, (name) will say or point to the meanings of (3) words from the definitions in a teacher-created word bank in (4 out of 5 consecutive trials as measured by teacher-made tests and student work samples).

goals.parent_text: In one year, you will be able to distinguish literal from nonliteral language in text.
goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Determine Literal and Figurative Language

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students reading the sentences or short passages, some students may benefit from using Text-to-Speech software. This will allow students who have trouble decoding words access to the grade level curriculum.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Support decoding text, mathematical notation, and symbols
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.3 Support decoding text, mathematical notation, and symbols

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students describing the meaning of words based on the words in their speaking / writing vocabulary, some students may benefit from having a word bank of descriptions to choose from. As students practice using words to describe other words or phrases, teachers can foster students' independence in this task.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of teachers selecting passages or sentences from typical grade level texts, some students may benefit from teachers selecting passages that are subjects of interest to the student (ex. a football book, a page from Diary of a Wimpy Kid, etc.).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.2 Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

goals.goal_text: By (date), when given two familiar grade level stories, (name) will verbally describe 2 ways in which two characters are similar and 2 ways in which they are different, as measured by (teacher observation).
goals.instruction_text: After a read aloud, teachers can lead students in an activity where they draw two characters then talk to a peer about their illustrations.
goals.measurement_text: After reading a familiar story, teachers can point to an illustration of two characters.  Then with support, teachers can ask students to tell them two things they have in common, and two things that makes them different.
goals.modification_text:
UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
Some students may need help identifying and using different categories for comparison. A graphic organizer or other teacher-made guide, suggesting important categories for comparison (e.g. biographical information, acts performed, etc.) may help these students to compare characters.

UDL II 5.2 Provide Multiple Means for Action and Expression: Use multiple tools for construction and composition
Allow students to use appropriate media when comparing two things. Some students will be more successful with verbal descriptions, others with written text, and others by constructing drawings.

objectives.text: By (date), when given two familiar, grade level stories and a [[concept mapping | visual concept map]] of two characters, (name) will verbally describe 2 ways in which two characters are similar and 2 ways in which they are different, as measured by (teacher observation).

By (date), when given two familiar, instructional level stories and a [[concept mapping | visual concept map]] of two characters, (name) will draw an [[illustration | illustration]] that shows 2 ways in which two characters are similar and 2 ways in which they are different, as measured by (teacher observation).

By (date), when [[Read Aloud | read aloud]] two instructional level, familiar stories and given a [[concept mapping | visual concept map]] of two characters, (name) will draw an [[illustration | illustration]] that shows 2 ways in which two characters are similar as measured by (teacher observation).

goals.parent_text: In one year, you will be able to compare and contrast two characters.
goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Compare and Contrast Adventures

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students comparing and contrasting characters simply from exposure to the stories, some students may benefit from a visual concept map about the characters. Teachers could make posters for each character with their unique qualities to share as visuals for students.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.4 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Maximize transfer and generalization
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.4 Maximize transfer and generalization

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students verbalizing how two characters are alike and different, some students may benefit from showing this in a visual way. Students could draw illustrations that show one similarity and one difference.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of asking students to describe one similarity and one difference after reading the story, teachers could create a visual checklist for students to complete the assignment (ex. Name, One similarity, One difference, Turn the paper in).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

goals.goal_text: By (date), when prompted to participate in a read aloud of a grade-level story, (name) will actively engage in group reading activities for (20) minutes (in 4 out of 5 trials) as measured by (teacher observation).
goals.instruction_text: Teacher can use visual reminders and routines to help students participate in group reading activities.
goals.measurement_text: Teachers can chart how often students participate in group reading activities.  Students should be able to meet all objectives in 4 out of 5 trials.
goals.modification_text:
UDL I 1.1 Provide Multiple Means for Representation: Offer ways of customizing the display of information
Some students need different kinds of reading materials (e.g. braille, enlarged text, etc.).

UDL II 6.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Guide appropriate goal-setting
Not all students will be able to read the exact same text at the exact same speed for the exact same length of time. Be sure to differentiate public reading expectations appropriately.

UDL III 8.4 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Increase mastery-oriented feedback
It may be difficult to provide constructive feedback to all students in reading groups at once. Assign reading groups appropriately so that each group is properly supervised. Give positive and constructive feedback to each reader.

objectives.text: With teacher prompting and support, (name) will sit with peers during a read-aloud for (_) minutes.
With teacher prompting and support, (name) will read (_) familiar sight words with peers during choral reading.
With teacher prompting and support, (name) will re-tell a familiar story to a peer.

By (date), when given background information on the book/topic then prompted to participate in a read aloud of a grade-level story, (name) will actively engage in group reading activities for (20) minutes (in 4 out of 5 trials) as measured by (teacher observation).

By (date), when given background information on the book/topic then prompted to participate in a read aloud of a familiar, grade-level story, (name) will actively engage in group reading activities for (20) minutes with the use of visual cue cards (in 4 out of 5 trials) as measured by (teacher observation).

By (date), when given background information on the book/topic then prompted to participate in a read aloud of an instructional-level story, (name) will actively engage in group reading activities for (20) minutes with the use of visual cue cards and positive reinforcements in intervals of (5) minutes (in 4 out of 5 trials) as measured by (teacher observation).

goals.parent_text: In one year, you will be able to participate in group reading activities.
goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Group Reading

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students participating in a read aloud of an unfamiliar text, students may benefit from receiving some background knowledge on the book/topic. Teachers can supply necessary background information to ensure all students can access the curriculum.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of students verbally participating in the group reading activity or read aloud, some students may benefit from the scaffolding of sentence starters or visuals that may help them express themselves appropriately in the reading group.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.2 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple tools for construction and composition
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.2 Use multiple tools for construction and composition

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of asking students to join the reading group without positive reinforcement, some students may benefit from a visual chart to display their participation in the reading group. For example, for every 5 minutes that a student can participate in the group, he/she may earn a sticker on a student-friendly chart. This will allow students and teachers to track their progress that is understandable to students.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Develop self-assessment and reflection
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.3 Develop self-assessment and reflection

goals.goal_text: By (date), when given a list of (10) one-syllable cue words, (name) will change a targeted sound (initial sound, medial sound and end sound) for each cue word and produce the new word correctly for (8/10) in (4 out of 5 consecutive trials) as measured by (teacher-charted records).
goals.instruction_text: Teachers can lead students in a guided practice activity where students change phonemes within words.
goals.measurement_text: Teachers can have students complete an activity where they change phonemes in words to make new words.
goals.modification_text:
UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
Students can be given explicit prompts to represent each sequential step of hearing the sounds within words and changing the individual sounds within words.

UDL I 1.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer alternatives for visual information
Teachers can complete the activity using poker chips or quarters to represent each sound within words.

objectives.text: By (date), when given a list of (10) one-syllable cue words and a [[ word wheels and letter flip charts | flip chart ]] that displays the targeted letter sound, (name) will use the flip chart to change a targeted sound (initial sound, medial sound and end sound) for each cue word and produce the new word correctly for (8/10) in (4 out of 5 consecutive trials) as measured by (teacher-charted records).

By (date), when given a list of (10) one-syllable cue words and a [[ word wheels and letter flip charts | movable "word wheel" ]] that displays the targeted letter sound, (name) will use the word wheel to change a targeted sound (initial sound, medial sound and end sound) for each cue word and produce the new word correctly for (8/10) in (4 out of 5 consecutive trials) as measured by (teacher-charted records).

By (date), when given a list of (10) one-syllable cue words and a [[ word bank | "letter bank" ]] of the appropriate vowels or consonants needed to complete the task, (name) with teacher guidance will change a targeted sound (initial sound, medial sound and end sound) for each cue word and produce the new word correctly for (8/10) in (4 out of 5 consecutive trials) as measured by (teacher-charted records).

goals.parent_text: Recognize and change the different sounds that make up each word.
goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Phoneme Isolation

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of teachers giving students cue words on paper, teachers can use a flip chart or letter cards to display and change the targeted letter sound. Teachers can also remove the targeted letter as well and provide a "letter bank" of the appropriate vowels or consonants needed to complete the task (i.e. _ nt, m_t, mo_; a, e, p).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 1.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer alternatives for visual information
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 1.3 Offer alternatives for visual information

udl_adaptations.text: Teachers can provide students with a movable "word wheel" to use for visual guidance in changing the targeted letter sound and stating the new word.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.2 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple tools for construction and composition
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.2 Use multiple tools for construction and composition

udl_adaptations.text: Teachers can provide different centers where students complete the same activity using different tools. At one center teachers can have students use letter tiles to fill in the missing or targeted part of the word (m_t) then state the word. At another center teachers can have students use dice that the letters written on each side to roll and use the letter facing up to fill in the missing part and create a new word.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Vary demands and resources to optimize challenge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.2 Vary demands and resources to optimize challenge

goals.goal_text: By (date), when listening to a list of (10) one or two-syllable words, (name) will count syllables for each orally read word, verbally stating the correct number of syllables for each word for (8/10) words in (4 of 5) words lists.
goals.instruction_text: Teachers can have students complete an activity where they segment and blend syllables into words using picture cards.
goals.measurement_text: Teachers can have students complete an activity where they segment words into syllables and graph them according to their number of syllables.
goals.modification_text:
UDL I 1.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer ways of customizing the display of information
Students can complete the activity using enlarged text or a document camera so that the text that can be enlarged.

UDL II 6.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Provide options for executive functions
Teachers can provide students with examples of the process and product of separating words into syllables.

UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster Collaboration and Communication
Teachers can allow students to complete the activity with a peer partner given clear expectations for group work.

objectives.text: By (date), when listening to a list of (10) one or two-syllable words, (name) will count syllables for each orally read word by clapping or tapping the syllables out, verbally stating the correct number of syllables for each word for (8/10) words in (4 of 5) word lists.

By (date), when listening to a list of (10) one or two-syllable words that is also visually presented on a [[ graphic organizers | graphic organizer ]], (name) will count syllables for each orally read word by clapping or tapping the syllables out, verbally stating the correct number of syllables for each word for (8/10) words in (4 of 5) word lists.

By (date), when listening to a list of (10) one or two-syllable words, (name) will count syllables for each orally read word by [[schedules | routinely]] saying the word while holding hand under chin with teacher support, verbally stating the correct number of syllables for each word for (8/10) words in (4 of 5) word lists.

goals.parent_text: Recognizing and counting syllables within words.
goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Counting Syllables

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of having students listen to a list of words, teachers can provide students with a list of words printed on a graphic organizer that guides the students in separating each word into the correct number of syllables.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Clarify vocabulary and symbols
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.1 Clarify vocabulary and symbols

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of having students count and say the correct number of syllables for each word, teachers can have students clap or tap the correct number of syllables to communicate their response.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: Teachers can provide students with a class routine of expected procedures for counting syllables within words. Teachers can create to procedure of having students place one of their hands under their chin while saying each word. Students can use the amount of times their chin moves as a guide for counting the syllables within each word.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Minimize threats and distractions
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.3 Minimize threats and distractions

goals.goal_text: By (date), when given (5) sets of (3) words that rhyme, (name) will produce a rhyming word for each set correctly in (4 out of 5 sets of rhyming words) as measured by (teacher-charted observations).
goals.instruction_text: Teacher can provide small group instruction on rhyming words. The teacher can model how to identify words that rhyme and should think out loud of examples of words that rhyme and words that do not rhyme. Teachers can then provide students with a guided practice activity where students draw pictures of words that rhyme.
goals.measurement_text: Teachers can evaluate this goal by having students draw a picture or name a word that rhymes when given a picture or oral prompt.
goals.modification_text:
UDL I 3.4 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Maximize transfer and generalization
Teachers can provide students with a graphic organizer that explicitly identifies examples of the rhyming sounds being used in the activity.

UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster Collaboration and Communication
Teachers can allow students to complete the activity with a peer partner given clear expectations for group work.

UDL I 1.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer ways of customizing the display of information
Students can complete the activity using enlarged pictures and text or a document camera so that the pictures and text that can be enlarged.

objectives.text: By (date), when given (5) sets of (3) words with [[ alternate text | pictures ]] that represent the words that rhyme, (name) will produce a rhyming word for each set correctly in (4 out of 5 sets of rhyming words) as measured by (teacher-charted observations).

By (date), when given (5) sets of (3) words with [[ alternate text | pictures ]] that represent the words that rhyme, (name) will select a [[ picture choices | picture card ]] that rhymes with the words for each set correctly in (4 out of 5 sets of rhyming words) as measured by (teacher-charted observations).

By (date), when given (5) sets of (3) words with [[ alternate text | pictures ]] that represent the words that rhyme and a teacher or [[ partner reading | peer ]] reading the words aloud, (name) will select a [[ picture choices | picture card ]] that rhymes with the words for each set correctly in (4 out of 5 sets of rhyming words) as measured by (teacher-charted observations).

goals.parent_text: Recognize and produce rhyming words.
goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Recognize and Produce Rhyming Words

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of providing rhyming words in the form of text, teachers can provide students with [[alternate text|alternate text]] in the form of pictures that rhyme.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 1.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer alternatives for visual information
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 1.3 Offer alternatives for visual information

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of having students verbally produce a rhyming word that matches the rhyme in each set, teachers can have students choose a word that rhymes with each set from a group of [[picture choices|picture cards]].
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of having students independently complete 5 sets of rhyming words in the activity, teachers can break the task into sequential subtasks where each step necessary for completing the task is outlined by identifying each procedure, numbering and ordering those procedures and putting it up in a place that the student can [[visual task schedule|view]]. This subtask checklist can be used to guide the students in the successful completion of the rhyme task.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Minimize threats and distractions
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.3 Minimize threats and distractions

goals.goal_text: By (date), when given a list of (15) single syllable short and long vowel words, (name) will be able to distinguish long vowel and short vowel words by circling the short vowel words and underlining the long vowel words scoring (12/15 correct responses) in (4 of 5 long and short vowel activities) as measured by (student work samples).
goals.instruction_text: Teachers can have students complete an activity where students match vowel sounds by sorting pictures into a long vowel or short vowel column.
goals.measurement_text: Teachers can have students complete an activity where students match vowel sounds by sorting pictures into a long vowel or short vowel column.
goals.modification_text:
UDL I 3.4 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Maximize transfer and generalization
Teachers can provide students with a graphic organizer that explicitly identifies examples of the long and short vowel sounds being used in the activity.

UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster Collaboration and Communication
Students can complete the activity with a peer partner given clear expectations for group work.

objectives.text: By (date), when given a list of (15) single syllable short and long vowel words with [[visual aids | picture representations]] of each word, (name) will be able to distinguish long vowel and short vowel words by circling the short vowel words and underlining the long vowel words scoring (12/15 correct responses) in (4 of 5 long and short vowel activities) as measured by (student work samples).

By (date), when given a list of (15) single syllable short and long vowel words that are [[read aloud | read aloud]], one at a time by the teacher, (name) will be able to distinguish long vowel and short vowel words by [[multiple choice | turning an index card]] that says "short" on one side and "long" on the other to the correct response for each word scoring (12/15 correct responses) in (4 of 5 long and short vowel activities) as measured by (student work samples).

By (date), when given a list of (15) single syllable short and long vowel words that are [[read aloud | read aloud]], one at a time by the teacher and positive [[ reinforcers | reinforcers]] per every response that follows the activities expectations, (name) will be able to distinguish long vowel and short vowel words by turning an index card that says "short" on one side and "long" on the other to the correct response for each word scoring (12/15 correct responses) in (4 of 5 long and short vowel activities) as measured by (student work samples).

goals.parent_text: Recognize the difference between short and long vowel sounds.
goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Short and Long Vowel Recognition

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of providing students with text during the short and long vowel recognition activity, teachers can [[ read aloud | read aloud ]] each word on the list as students circle or underline the short and long vowel words. Teachers can also provide [[ picture choices | picture representations ]] of each word to visually provide each student with access to the task.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 1.2 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer alternatives for auditory information
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 1.2 Offer alternatives for auditory information

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of having students circle the short vowel words and underline the long vowel words, teachers can read each word on the list, one at a time, while students select and display the correct response by turning an index card that says "short" on one side and "long" on the other to the appropriate side.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: To help the students stay on task and highly engaged during the short and long vowel activity, teachers can give students a positive reinforcer(i.e. an m&m, a sticker, a stamp, a token) for each response that follows the activity's expectations for behavior.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

goals.goal_text: By (date), when given (10) grade level words (e.g. CVC, CVCe) with [[ visual aids | pictorial representations ]], (name) will identify and segment, beginning, middle, and ending sounds and verbally blend the sounds together to make a recognizable word with (8 out of 10) correct responses in (4 of 5) sound activities as measured by (teacher-made tests/charted records).
goals.instruction_text: Teachers can guide students in a practice activity where students look at pictures and orally say each sound that makes up the word.
goals.measurement_text: Teachers can have students complete an independent practice activity where students look at pictures and orally say each sound that makes up the word then put each sound together to say the completed word.
goals.modification_text:
UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
Students can be given explicit prompts to represent each sequential step of hearing the sounds within words and changing the individual sounds within words.

UDL I 1.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer alternatives for visual information
Students can complete the activity using poker chips or quarters to represent each sound within words.

objectives.text: By (date), when given (10) grade level words (e.g. CVC, CVCe) with [[ visual aids | pictorial representations ]], (name) will identify and segment, beginning, middle, and ending sounds and verbally blend the sounds together to make a recognizable word with (8 out of 10) correct responses in (4 of 5) sound activities as measured by (teacher-made tests/charted records).

By (date), when given (10) instructional level words (e.g. CVC's) with [[ visual aids | pictorial representations ]] and [[ Elkonin Boxes | Elkonin boxes]] with [[counters|counters]], (name) will identify and segment, beginning, middle, and ending sounds and verbally blend the sounds together to make a recognizable word with (8 out of 10) correct responses in (4 of 5) sound activities as measured by (teacher-made tests/charted records).

By (date), when given (10) instructional level words with [[ visual aids | pictorial representations ]] and [[ Elkonin Boxes | Elkonin boxes]] with [[counters|counters]], (name) and a [[ partner reading | peer partner ]] will identify and segment, beginning, middle, and ending sounds and verbally blend the sounds together to make a recognizable word with (8 out of 10) correct responses in (4 of 5) sound activities as measured by (teacher-made tests/charted records).

goals.parent_text: Recognize, blend and segment the sounds within words.
goals.subject: Reading
goals.title: Recognize, Blend and Segment Sounds

udl_adaptations.text: Teachers can provide students with [[visual aids|pictorial representations]] of words alongside a [[graphic organizers|template]] that includes the appropriate number of blank lines ( ___  ___  ___) representing each letter needed to create the word. The blank lines can be placed underneath of the picture. These templates can be used to guide students in identifying, segmenting or blending the sounds in each word.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 1.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer alternatives for visual information
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 1.3 Offer alternatives for visual information
